bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 161, Number 61 (Monday, April 27, 2015)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. YOUNG of Alaska:H.R. 2038.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2 of the United StatesConstitution.____________________[Page H2475]

item.name: Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Subcommittee

latestAction.text: Received in the Senate and Read twice and referred to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and Transportation.
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under General Orders. Calendar No. 302.

item.name: Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation Subcommittee

item.text: Referred to the Subcommittee on Coast Guard and Maritime Transportation.
Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

summary.text:
This bill authorizes the Coast Guard (CG) to convey 3.25 acres of CG real property (including all improvements located on the property) in Tok, Alaska, upon payment to the United States of the fair market value of the property.

The Tanana Chief's Conference shall have the right of first refusal to purchase the property.

The property must be sold at fair market value.

The United States shall deposit the proceeds in the CG Housing Fund.

bill.title: To authorize the conveyance of certain Coast Guard property in Tok, Alaska, and for other purposes.

item.title: To authorize the conveyance of certain Coast Guard property in Tok, Alaska, and for other purposes.
To authorize the conveyance of certain Coast Guard property in Tok, Alaska, and for other purposes.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
